runner's high was was hard to explain
from a neuroscience perspective for a
long time there was a disconnect between
the kind of the popular press and
neuroscientist as a populist press but
of course endorphins is causing it all
but from the neuroscience perspective we
had information that endorphins in your
peripheral nervous system in your body
was going up but that doesn't mean that
endorphins were actually also going up
in your brain and that it was doing
anything to your brains pleasure centers
only recently have we gotten direct
evidence that in fact endorphins are
going up during and after a run and this
was a study done in kind of long-term
long distance runners and that they are
binding to those parts of the brain that
are stimulating because metaphoric
feeling so we still don't know the exact
time course how long you have to do it
and anecdotally everybody get to that
level so it may be individual
differences maybe some people have more
endorphin receptors and less endorphins
receptors but it's clear that it is
endorphins that is partially responsible
for that runner's high and we'd like to
try and take advantage of that so people
can really get the motivational benefits
of that to continue exercising
